Dialog.Content: The Rhinos wield significant combat prowess, but they are easily agitated and can cause collateral damage to the point of reducing the facility to rubble.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …That guy sure looked tough and dependable. What did they tell you about the Reindeer?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I was told that they use psychological attacks.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: While the machines would’ve been relatively safe from them, they still had a risk of causing irreversible damage to the manager.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: In a nutshell, the Rabbits were the only team suitable for that facility, huh.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That’s right. Of course, the Rabbits did make matters worse sometimes…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: But all in all, they were quite helpful.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: The air feels heavy.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: This atmosphere makes me feel as though we’re in the Ruins.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: A Star of the City is not much different from the Ruins in terms of danger.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Aren’t you guys excited to graze some fresh grass?

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Myo, please keep your mouth shut for five minutes.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Greetings, dear guests. I am Angela, the director and librarian of my role’s namesake.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Greetings. I am Nikolai, leader of the Fourth Pack of R Corp.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Been a while, Angela! I’ll drop the formality since the contract’s over.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It’s good to see a familiar face.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: You broke L Corp, didn’t cha?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What makes you think that, I wonder?

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: I figured your rotten mind would do something huge someday the first time I met you.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: You can’t fool my gut feeling. Thanks to you, we’re all about to be destroyed.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You’re still rambling stupid nonsense, unable to read the mood. If you’re so curious, you can read a book to find out.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Oh, in case you don’t know what a book is… It’s a little bundle of pages made of paper that you can hold in your hands and read.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: You’re playing grown up in your little Library after you’re done being a puppet secretary, huh?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Are you offended that I might have killed the Red Mist, the woman you were such a big fan of?

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: …Myo, I told you to shut up. And you, I’m intrigued by what you said.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Could you guide us inside first?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Of course. May you find your book in this place.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: How’s it feel to be looking at the book of your old friend?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Friend? She was little more than an acquaintance, as I said before.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: True, but she was still one of the few people that have known you for a long time.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: She’s a former associate of yours, which I’m sure is a rarity among the guests. Doesn’t it feel odd or anything?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …It did leave a curious impression. That’s all there is to it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Nonetheless, I wasn’t planning to go easy on her regardless of my feelings. We have a purpose clearly cut out for us, and so do the guests.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Don’t you think gaining freedom by devouring everything will leave a bitter taste in your mouth?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I don’t know.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: But right now, I want to focus on heading towards this goal I have. I don’t want to pay attention to what’s around me…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Taking these steps is hard enough for me.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You don’t want to have any regret, huh.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Roland, you don’t seem to get tired of asking if I have regrets.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, I mean, you may have been ignorant of everything at first, but…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’ve seen and experienced many different things on the way here.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I was just wondering if those experiences changed your thoughts a little.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: A person’s aims and wishes… don’t stay the same forever, you know.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I don’t know about that.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Huff… Is Myo the only one remaining now?

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Yes, ma’am.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Wanna bet which Myo will win?

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: I’m surprised you still aren’t sick of this.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: As much as I dislike that rabid hare… this is the one scene I don’t like to see.
Dammit! Looks like I died again!
We have to do this fuckery over more?
Stop whining, we’ve been through this many times already.
Let’s hurry up and decide the winner now.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: One day with the TT2 protocol at 100-fold output… That’ll cost a lot of energy.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: You usually gave us a week.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: I know that sufficient time and population are needed, but we cannot afford to wait any longer.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: One day accelerated 100 times would be about three months.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: And there’s about five thousand Myos.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Man, having to fight ten thousand clones of myself for a whole year was pure hell… We had it easier this time!
Shit! Shit! Shit!!!
That’s about half of us dead.
Reminds you of the old days, doesn’t it?
The first time I killed me?
My hands were shaking like crazy…
Keep killing if you have the time to chat!

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: Then we’ll explain the terms and conditions again.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: As per A Corp’s rules, no more than one of an individual may exist in the City for longer than 7 days, clone or original.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: If R Corp. violates this rule, it will lose its qualification as a Wing and will be shut down according to B Corp’s regulations.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: The “7 days” here is measured based on the time scale A Corp. is on.
Die! Die! DIE!!!
Crap! I’ve been feeding on human meat for two months… And it’s my meat, too.
Better than living on it for one year straight.
Why do we have to kill each other, why?!
You still don’t get it? It’s to produce the fittest Myo.
Some still lose their minds like that even after killing many others. It’s odd how clones of the same person can act so differently.
You’re telling me, most of us are thrilled to kill people now.
Because killing was literally the only way to survive!

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: This is but a digression, but… you’ll have to be more conservative with using R Corp’s hatchery, or the cloning machine in other words.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: Because L Corp. went down so suddenly, we don’t have enough energy suppliers to meet the demands right now.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: W Corp. is apparently in emergency for the same reason.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: I suppose so. I heard from the supreme commander that L Corp. was extraordinarily generous about its offer.
I cried a lot at first…
Mmhmm. Shocked that I had to kill myself…
But after killing myself again and again, it became as easy as breathing.
If I can kill myself with ease, what’s to stop me from killing others.
And the joy of being the last survivor was something else.
It was piss annoying to wake up every time with all the memories of struggling to survive, though.
It’s all thanks to the word of advice the Red Mist gave me that I could withstand these hellish times.
It’s not the strong who survive…
It’s the survivors who are strong.
Khh~ The legendary Red Mist rescues me like a hero in the Backstreets, says that, and leaves… Wasn’t it awesome?!
You bet it was.
Let’s get back to business and see who survives now.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: For the reasons stated, this will probably be the last time the Fourth Pack can hatch.

Dialog.Title: T Corporation
Dialog.Content: If you fail again, there won’t be a next chance.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: I’ve been expecting that.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: There wouldn’t be any energy left to use for us.
It seems the two of us had the tightest grips on life.
No need to hesitate. This is our last fight, so let’s end this with no regret.

Place.PlaceName: Location: R Corp - Fourth Pack Conference Room

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Looks like I got out last this time.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: It’s good to see you, rabbit.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: What?! Why the hell would you greet me?!

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Aw, shit!

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: …Hey, you guys made another bet, didn’t you?!

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: We did, Number 635.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: The tab’s on you next time we get a drink, Maxim.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: I was so sure Myo #17 would make it. She seemed to have keen senses…

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: 17 was a tricky foe, not gonna lie.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: By the way, Maxim! You’re paying for my drink too, right?

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: …For sure. That’s the rule of the bet.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Hah… Alright, it’s payback time! Let’s wreck those librarians or some shit!

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s what the Singularity of R Corp. was…?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They said two of the same person can’t exist at once for a week. What is the reason they set such a peculiar rule?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Don’t ask me. I don’t wanna know the answer to that…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: If it was possible to clone dead humans…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Then why did he create me… And the Sephirot.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: He was willing to break any rules or conditions…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, that technology could have its fair share of flaws if we look at it in detail.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Might need several preparatory steps, or some sort of permit, all that…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It could be more complicated than it seems on the surface. Maybe what the person you’re talking about did was the best option for him at that moment.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Still, I’m astounded by it alright. There really is a cloning technology for humans.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: They can roll with it as long as no more than one of the person exists for longer than a week… What were they thinking there…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …This ‘clone’ business feels rather similar to what I’d gone through.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …I didn’t expect them to be used so ruthlessly, even if they’re clones.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Are they gonna be stronger than the versions that we received the last time?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I can’t say for certain.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: We’re facing elites that competed against thousands of themselves and came out on top… I imagine it won’t be a pushover.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: The air feels heavy.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: This atmosphere makes me feel as though we’re in the Ruins.

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: A Star of the City is not much different from the Ruins in terms of danger.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: And we all died here once.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Still though, aren’t you guys excited to graze some fresh grass?

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Myo, please keep your mouth shut for five minutes.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I welcome you once again, dear guests. I am Angela, director and librarian of my role’s namesake.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Greetings. I am Nikolai, leader of the Fourth Pack of R Corp.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You’re saying the same thing as last time.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: …Am I.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Been a while, Angela! I’ll drop the formality since the contract’s over.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Don’t you have any problem?

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: With what?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You… You’ve killed countless clones of yourself.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: …So?

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: …Tell me, library director. How much do you know?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: How can any of you remain sane?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You are humans.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: How is it possible that your mind hasn’t collapsed?

Dialog.Title: Reindeer Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: Captain, I think she’s aware.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: I see. This must be the power of the Library.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Are you surprised with our way of life?

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: Perhaps it may seem so for a being that is staying in a sheltered environment like a precious flower.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: But this is nothing compared to what we have seen previously in our lives.

Dialog.Title: Rhino Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: We have no problem enduring it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You know nothing of my life. You’re…

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: You’re right, we know fuck all about it. So stop being a pissy little crybaby, and let’s just go about our separate ways.

Dialog.Title: Rabbit Team Leader - 4th Pack of R Corp.
Dialog.Content: We don’t wanna die here twice, y’know? I don’t care how you lived, and I don’t feel like wasting any of my time listening to it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Such is the life of the City.

Dialog.Title: R Corp. 4th Pack Captain
Dialog.Content: You know it well.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: May you find your book in this place.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Roland, do you think I’m being a crybaby, too?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Nope. I don’t think so at all, speaking as someone who got to see what kind of life you’ve lived—albeit indirectly.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I’m starting to feel a little scared.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’m scared that the anguish I’m bearing might be something anyone can stomach and I’m making a big deal about it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They said they’d been through worse. That they can bear that much.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Is it actually because… I have no such experience…?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Is that why I am suffering so much agony from what is virtually nothing to them?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Don’t let it bother you. The agony you’re carrying right now is the only thing that matters.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You just have to remember the pain and keep moving forward. Don’t let what others say or might say about your pain get to you.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You don’t have to shoehorn yourself into someone else’s standards.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Are you saying that each person deals with it in different ways?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, that’s basically it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: They like to set up standards and accuse some people of acting like a baby or making a big fuss over nothing… It’s better to just ignore that.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Thank you. That cheered me up a little.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Don’t mention it. I’m just telling you what I believe in.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Why, you managed to up the ante pretty quickly, kid in Blue?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: It’s all thanks to your advice, my dear mentor.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Without your help, I couldn’t have come this far or joined hands with this wonderful crew of allies.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Come on, you’re flattering me. You’re not the type to say such things.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Wouldn’t you like to join us?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Sorry, but I’m just not cut out for music.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That’s a pity. I’d really love to return the favor somehow.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You were the only one who showed me the light when I was lost, dear mentor.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Honestly, I thought you were little more than some deranged maniac until you came to me.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: My, you’ve got no breaks on your mouth.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: So, how are things going for you?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: The Puppeteer, Blood-red Night, L’heure du Loup, Yesterday’s Promise, the leader of the Church of Gears, the 8 o’Clock Circus, The Musicians of Bremen, The Crying Children, and one of the Eight Chefs…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’ve gathered the members so sweetly.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: And we’ve nourished the Library just as you advised.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: You were so quick about it, it’s almost obese at this point.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’m so excited, you see?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I can finally be myself soon enough…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I was lonely, to tell you the truth. So painfully lonely.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: The loneliness born from the belief that we could never understand each other.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: The two of you suffered terrible things at such a young age, so the bond between you both must’ve been even more special.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You’re right. I had thought the only reason I lived was because my sister was alive…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Because Angelica hadn’t died yet.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: But even after Angelica left me…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I was terribly lonely, yet I wanted to live.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I just couldn’t give up my life with my own hands by any means.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Then I had a realization: I was just suspending the inevitable.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That I had merely put the meaning of my life on Angelica and run from it.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: The performance that will soon echo through the City will be my journey to seek the meaning to live… and be the proof of my life.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: All of us will be freed from loneliness.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: It’s a farewell to this gloomy and solitary City.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Like the Pianist, all of us can become one and perform together.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: That’s touching.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: A dirge for Angelica… Yes. You said the power of the Distortion would be needed if I wanted to spread the beautiful melody Angelica showed me through every corner of the City.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Thanks to that advice, I managed to form a wonderful crew.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Take a look at the members of the ensemble, dear mentor. They can’t be compared to the humans corroded by the City.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: They were abandoned, scorned… struggled in anguish and sorrow after what they cherished was taken from them…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: But they didn’t give up; they clawed their way out of the deep dark abyss, and found their truest forms…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: True strength can only be pulled out of filthy, fathomless pits of despair… Nothing could rival such beauty, don’t you agree?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: With a crew like this… I’ll be able to inscribe that tune into every part of the City once again.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: While I get that your mind is brimming with enthusiasm… It’s not a won game yet, though, is it?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: You still have to take the Library’s Light in your own hands.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Hahaha… Ah, you’re right. I was elated like a little child for a moment.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Even though it’s still not in my grasp just yet…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That light… I could almost touch it, but not quite snatch it…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Iori, dear. I’m curious about why you live on.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Hadn’t you lost all meaning to your life ages ago?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’m pretty sure you’re lonelier than most.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Yet you still refuse to join us.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: That’s harsh, kid. I do have at least one reason to live, you know?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I wonder if it’s true that you know everything, dear mentor.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’m grateful from the bottom of my heart for you coming to me and helping us prepare our performance.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I thought you were helping me out of pity… I believed you were motivated by pure sympathy for me.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: But… the person in our hearts is bawling at us, telling us that it’s not true.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …The person in your heart?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Yes. She speaks to me in such a wondrous and clear voice, a voice I’d never ever heard in this world.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Now, Iori… Could she be speaking the truth?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Then, what’s the true motive behind my dear teacher’s assistance?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Dunno. My guess is as good as yours.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Maybe looking at you reminded me of my son…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: What? Hahaha…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Ah, Iori… You’re such a tearjerker.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Your son died more than 40 years ago…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: …What’s your true motive in helping me?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: I thought you’d always remain a dorky and naive little kid… Looks like you’ve grown smarter after making friends and stuff, huh?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: I just needed to give you a helping hand so I could reach a place I wanted to go.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Mhm. A place you want to go, is it.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Where could you be wanting to go so desperately to treat me with such kindness…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You have the ability to jump between dimensions, you should be able to go anywhere and know anything with ease…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Kid. This power isn’t as easily abusable as you might think.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Enough of this fluff…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I don’t want you living any longer, Iori.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You knew I was going to do this, didn’t you?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: What is my all-knowing mentor going to do now, I wonder…

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: For your information, even you will have a hard time escaping the thick layer of barriers I’ve set up.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …Pipe Organ.

Dialog.Title: Church of Gears Leader
Dialog.Content: That brain of yours you put to work was far inferior to my Thought Gears.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …Harp.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: How about I break ‘er arms and legs before she can think about running away.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …Viola.

Dialog.Title: The Crying Children
Dialog.Content: You’ve lost something precious to you… Surely you can understand us.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …Cello.

Dialog.Title: The 8 o’Clock Ringmaster
Dialog.Content: Aha! How about a snake show drenched in strawberry juice?! The fleshy fruit will make an explosive display!

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Clarinet…

Dialog.Title: The Musicians of Bremen
Dialog.Content: Bwakbwak!! Arfarfbwaeghii!!! NEIIIGHRUFFHIIII~!!

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Horn… Tuba… Trombone.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I wonder what your veins taste like…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: First Violin…

Dialog.Title: The Eight Chefs
Dialog.Content: It’s no good eating them raw, sister. I’ll make a fine pasta out of her veins once you get ‘em out! Rosé sauce would go well with it. Hawhawhaw!

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: …Percussion.

Dialog.Title: Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Leave some flesh and bones for me. My puppetry isn’t done yet…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: And Second Violin.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Iori… We don’t need you anymore.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: That’s funny. Welp…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: It might have been but a brief moment to you guys, but for me, it was a long and valuable time.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Please don’t talk nonsense all of a sudden.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Now, I have places to be…

Dialog.Title: Church of Gears Leader
Dialog.Content: Sir Argalia! She has the invitation!

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Tch…! Stop her!

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Iori, let me ask you one question.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Angela! You have a guest waiting at the door!

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: …Can you sincerely not hear her mesmerizing voice?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …That’s why he’s been recruiting Distortions.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m starting to see why he’s been up to his crazy antics now.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What’s with that face? Anything bothering you?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They said they’re after the Library’s Light.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That means their aim… overlaps with ours.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I guess so. …Are you scared that they’d steal it from you?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: No. You and the other librarians are handling receptions well enough. I have much faith in you.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Though, I would be lying if I said I had no fear.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You can just say that you don’t trust us enough.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That’s not it. Something’s… different.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Your attitude being one of those differences. You were full of pride when R Corp. challenged us. Heck, you were confident pretty much all the time.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …You’re right. I wonder why.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Most of the guests we’ve greeted so far had a vague purpose. They only sought to earn the books and get back.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Not to have the books themselves, either… Most were planning to give them to their superiors, such as the leader of the Syndicate or the higher-ups of the Association. Of course, all of it was done on the premise that it’ll ultimately bring happiness to themselves.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: But the Ensemble is different.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They have a clear objective. And their goal is the same thing I seek.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: There’s a considerable contrast between those who act in the interests of others and those who act strictly for themselves.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I never had to worry about it being taken in the past, but the situation has changed now, hasn’t it?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So, what I’m getting at is that they scare you because their goal is taking the thing you’re gathering, and not because they might be too strong?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Yes. Now theft has become a concern of mine thanks to them.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Phew~ That was a close call.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Age hasn’t stopped my heart from still being so excitable.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: That aside, this place handles transportation pretty gently, unlike how I do it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Greetings, dear guest.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Everyone and their mother’s heard about you and your Library by now, so let’s skip the introductions.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Since you probably saw what was going on out there… You have a basic idea of how things went, yeah?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …You’re rather knowledgeable.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Looking at the state of the Library… Guess I didn’t have to worry so much.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: And you seem to be making steady progress towards becoming a human, too.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: All thanks to the kiddo being quick to set up the stage, huh?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Then why are you helping me?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Helping you?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You ensured the steady growth of the Library in substance. Am I wrong?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: I just couldn’t leave the kid in Blue be.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You want us to make sure that the Blue Sicko and his friends can’t get their hands on the Library’s power?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Take it however you will.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: And extract a book from me. It’ll be pretty helpful.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: I have a fair amount of info in my head.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You’re asking to be killed nonchalantly… Are all Colors out of their minds?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Course I’m not. I’ll fight with all my strength.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: If you can’t best this old woman… I’ll ruin the Library in my own way.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Although I can’t completely kill you, I do have a number of ideas for breaking a being that has become quite close to human.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I get what you’re saying. Why don’t you cut the nonsense and get inside now?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: The director of a library where countless bits of knowledge are accumulated wants to part with her past memories…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: What irony.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Just focus on finding your book.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Gee, aren’t you cold. But if that’s what the library director says, I gotta listen.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Oh, and one more thing…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: May you find your book in this place.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Whoops… There she goes. I wanted to hear more about the kid here.

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: He seemed pretty unstable back then…

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: Still, I guess he also played a part in helping the Library expand so much, huh?

Dialog.Title: The Purple Tear
Dialog.Content: All right. Let’s see how great this Library place is, shall we?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The Purple Tear… That was the name of the Color. She was quite competent indeed.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The ability to jump between dimensions…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The Purple Tear didn’t appear to be interested in getting books.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: She came here because she didn’t want the Blue Reverberation’s band ganging up on her.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: If she took shelter here to avoid death, I’m sure she could have thought of other ways to live…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Yet the Purple Tear fought to the end, ultimately becoming a book.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: She said peculiar things, like telling me to turn her into a book… Why was that, I wonder?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Wanting to avoid the Reverb Ensemble could be a superficial reason.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The real reason the Purple Tear entered this place will be carried to the bookshelf with her.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And, you know, the power might not be all omnipotent.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m pretty sure there was a reason she couldn’t just leave here. Maybe there’s some kinda… barrier surrounding this place.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: A barrier…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …No guest that has been invited to this place could maintain composure until the last moment like the Purple Tear did.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: She was treated like an all-knowing sage… She might have been aware of her own future, at least.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Could she have knowledge about the Library as well?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Beats me. Even if the Purple Tear did know about it, there’s nothing she can do for it since she’s turned into a book now.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Yeah. You’re right.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You seem kinda unnerved as of late.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I suppose that’s part of the process of becoming a human.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: When people feel anxiety, they tend to buckle up and prepare more thoroughly for what’s to come, you see?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: This is one of those times. It could be a chance for you to think deeper about things.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …And grow as an individual.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Nevermind. I appreciate your hard work dealing with a Color.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I get that inviting powerful guests will promote the Library’s growth, but…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Boy, receiving a couple more Colors or people on that level is gonna tire the whole Library out.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You still do a good job every time.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I want to say thank you to you and all the other librarians, Roland. Please sort the books before you go.
Fine, I don’t need to hear another word from you. If you’re so fearful of death, leave me and escape by yourself!
I wouldn’t have brought you with me if I were such a coward fearing for my life!
There has to be some reason you’ve done this, then…
If your reasoning is unsatisfactory, know that there will be consequences to your actions!
Director…
Your battle will be nothing more than a messy scrape if you try to keep up in your current state, ma’am! You have to have realized it yourself!
Out of my way!!!
…Step aside. I am as composed as I can be.
You can’t even best your own subordinate right now, director.
There is nothing composed about charging blindly into the fray and brandishing your sword like a madwoman…
They’re foes that we must destroy anyway!
In fact, I would argue that it’s better this way, as I can firmly grasp my blade with an undaunted heart, unshaken by fear.
…Even if they were opponents that warrant such a fight, wielding your blade while you’ve lost yourself will only yield a pointless and juvenile revenge.
They say anger is needed in order to face the enemy, but an excess of that emotion will ultimately hurt yourself.
Fury shouldn’t be the only motivation to bestir oneself… I thought you knew this well, director.
You’re the one who taught me that I’ll spill my own blood if I can’t see where the edge of my sword is pointed, after all…
I have no resolve to show to those who have taken what is mine.
They had the nerve to make an offer where we must put our lives on the line to earn it back. Such absurdity.
Now tell me why I should treat them with any courtesy!
Even then!
That’s not how Lowell would’ve reacted! So please, Xiao… Gather your senses.
Miris… I am aware. I know that the Library didn’t snatch Lowell and Section 2 away from us.
I am well aware that they took a fair offer and made a bet, and paid the rightful price for losing it.
But what can I do when I simply cannot bring myself to accept that?
Was it truly done of their own volition?
Can anyone say with utmost certainty that no coercion was involved in their decision!
Whenever my mind was plagued with such thoughts, I couldn’t make rational judgement…
Is it because Chun and the other Fixers are dead? Is that why you’re acting like this?
You would be right. At first, I thought I only had to care about my own safety.
As long as I could get my hands on Lowell’s book…
I decided that I wouldn’t care about my surroundings, even if that meant I would have no one to rely on once everything was over.
But, as I saw my colleagues die out one by one, my mind began to waver…
Am I truly going down the righteous path?
Is it truly right as a human being to think of myself, and only myself?
When the many of those who trusted me and followed me have perished, should I overlook their deaths and keep moving forward…?
If my selfishness is causing harm to others, shouldn’t I stop it before it’s too late? Shouldn’t I save those who still have a chance?
If I had to make a choice, who should be putting up with the hardship? Is it you, or I?
Miris… Answer me. I’m no longer certain what I should put first.
…I’m not one to give you an answer for that. How should I know better than you about yourself? You know I’m not in any way wiser than you.
Here’s what I can say, Xiao… None of the Fixers who followed you here were forced by anyone to do so, and I’m no different.
There can’t be any compulsion about trusting you and willingly following your lead, now can there…
Call it heartless, but as with everyone else… If it was your power that we were after, we would’ve left you once your authority faded.
You’ve stepped down from the Liu’s Section 1. You’re not in the position to pressure us anymore, and we aren’t obligated by any duty to obey you.
What you’re saying is that I can stick to my belief and move on, the same way you kept believing in me, and acted for me.
Like a cup of tea that maintains its good scent after half is gone, and a quarter of a day has passed…
…Xiao?
Don’t you… hear a sound?
A warm and charming voice… almost as if it were out of this world…
What are you talking about? I don’t hear anything other than our own voices.
…What?
…You’re wrong. No, maybe there is truth to what you said…
Are you calling me selfish?
…No, I don’t think so.
…A human cannot live alone. No man is an island entire of itself.
They need someone else… Yes.
Someone whom I will keep alive. Someone who will become the reason for me to keep on living, no matter what…
Someone can be alive because I am there with them… As that person can live thanks to me, I myself should not expire.
A way to protect you all and myself at the same time…
I shouldn’t die. By cherishing myself, I am cherishing the people around me…
Therefore, what you’re saying… isn’t right. I won’t be deceived by your temptation…
…Yes. I suppose this is what you meant when you said a selfish mind shouldn’t be viewed negatively.
I’m sorry. I had let my own emotions overwhelm me and failed to lead you rightly.
This will be the last time I apologize to you and everyone else.
Miris… I’m still in the dark, and I cannot see ahead.
I’m frankly afraid, and I might stray onto wrong paths sometimes.
However, I trust myself to return to the proper way as I stoutly press onward. Just because I cannot see the way ahead, does not mean that a way doesn’t exist.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Did she manifest E.G.O just now?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That certainly resembled E.G.O, although it was incomplete like Philip’s.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And she was mumbling to herself, but it sounded like she was talking to someone.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The voice we couldn’t hear, but Xiao could…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Kinda like Abnormalities.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What do you mean by that?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I can hear some sort of voices whenever I borrow strength from the Abnormalities here.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The other librarians can’t hear what I hear. The voice is only audible to one person.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Sometimes, a voice filled with rage rings through my head, and other times I hear a sorrowful wail…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And my mind gets sorta… shaken… by those voices somehow.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Listening to it sometimes makes me feel something is boiling up inside me, or cooling my head down all of a sudden.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I think the voice Xiao heard is different from the ones you and Gebura hear.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: In what way?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The voices you hear will only say whatever they want to say, one-sidedly. I’m sure there are exceptions, but most will probably behave that way.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: On the other hand, Xiao was talking with the voice. She was in a conversation with whispers that seemed to want something to happen to her.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hmm… I’m not so sure. We don’t have solid evidence to prove that the voice was different just yet.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Anyhow… We’ve gotta receive her before anything. The problem is how we’re gonna deal with that figurative beast of a person…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: In the end, Xiao has become a book.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: She didn’t break down like the other kid with the power did, at least. I was actually amazed by how unswerving her determination could be…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Lost deep in thought again? What is it this time?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’ve been thinking about the distinctions between E.G.O and the Distortion after watching Philip and Xiao.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The two were similar yet different. They clearly had some things in common, but the contrast was apparent as well.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Really? Tell me your thoughts, then.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I think there is something that can restrain one from reaching the point of the Distortion.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They both had highly unstable emotions, enough to touch the threshold of manifesting E.G.O or Distortion. And those emotions had a similar nature.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Egoism…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: As in the mindset of only caring about your own interest?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That’s it. The two interpreted that same selfishness in disparate ways, however.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Because that selfish mind had the potential to change the self, the two were able to take a form resembling E.G.O, albeit incompletely.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Philip’s mindset was flawed even in his awakening, however. He still had distrust in the back of his mind.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I think Xiao had the same problem, too. She didn’t look like she had full conviction at the start. It took some time for her to make up her mind.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That’s where the two differ. As far as I can see…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …It had something to do with the voices only they could hear, I believe.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The voices, huh…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Indeed. Philip’s mind was in such a vulnerable state, even Oswald’s words could crack him.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I don’t know what the disembodied voice Pluto told Philip to “pay close attention to” said, or if the voice really was the last straw that broke him…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: But I could speculate a little based on what we saw of Xiao.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: She didn’t give in to the voice whispering to her… Instead, her will solidified further.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And she managed to fully manifest her own E.G.O.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Right. She was able to resist the voice’s snare… I wonder why she could.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It might be what she said when she first came here… The precious things and whatever.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: All the things that motivate humans to live, to be precise.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I guess it’s not something that can be pinned down to one specific element. Each person cherishes different things.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Maybe E.G.O is the thing that keeps one from crossing the line of the Distortion.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s like walking a tightrope at all times. One wrong step and you crash to the ground.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I suppose you’re right, Roland.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s weird, though. It can’t be possible to make any change with just willpower in this world. That’s not how this City works.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Maybe the world is about to change, then.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s not as simple as that. If this power really has the potential to shift the ecology of the City, the Head could take action at any time.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Even if the Head does intervene, it won’t make a difference.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: We’ll simply greet them as guests, like any other.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …L5123’s… fourth door.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Fourteen steps to the right… Twenty-three steps to the left…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …There’s a staircase.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: How… far down does this go…?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: The sound, it’s getting louder… And I see a dim light…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Is it really okay to head inside?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: I guess I have no choice.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …What’s this…? What are these huge machinations supposed to be…

Dialog.Title: Index Constituent
Dialog.Content: Welcome~ Welcome~! It must’ve been an exhausting journey here, come on in and make yourself at home~!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Who are you?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: I’m the Weaver working here!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: It’s so nice to see a guest after such a long time. Come on, now! Don’t be shy and step right in!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: A Weaver…?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Yep, that’s what I am.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: You were invited by the Prescript, right…?!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: How did you…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The likes of you couldn’t even dream of finding this place without the guidance of the Prescript!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: It only invites people here on a very extraordinary occasion, so consider yourself honored~!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Does this place have something to do with the Prescripts?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Yes-oh-yes, it has plenty to do with them. This is the birthplace of Prescripts.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Prescripts are born?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Your face tells me that you must have a lot you’d like to hear!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: And that’s good! I was really bored, too, actually… You should take a seat first, here. This will be a loooong story! Here’s your chair…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Sorry I have no tea. It’s hard to come by warm water down here… Oh, where are my manners. What’s your name? Are you a Proxy? Or a Messenger? My name’s Moirai!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: H-hold on. Could you please slow down…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: First off, I’m Yan… Yan Vismok… I’m a Messenger. I only started working less than a month ago…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Yan! So you were a Messenger.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Yes… I’ve been delivering Prescripts full of absurd and brutal orders.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Oh, I understand. Prescripts are cruel indeed. And knotty, too, which gets some people killed.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …I had to hear many resentful remarks and screams from the people who received their Prescripts.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Are you… Are you the one who wrote those ridiculous Prescripts?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Yeesh, so scary! Don’t scowl at me so dreadfully, now.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: To answer your question first…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: No, I’m not responsible for the contents of the Prescripts. My occupation is to manage these spinning wheels and loom.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Huh? Then how are Prescripts “born”…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Shh.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Can you hear this sound? Can you feel the tremor, climbing up your feet and touching your bosom?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …I can feel a tiny quake, yes. But… what about it? It’s just a small vibration.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Wrong! This isn’t a simple tremor.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: You’re feeling the heartbeat of the City.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: It vibrates at random frequencies…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Those vibrations move this pendulum over here… and I spin the wheels to make threads.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Oh, why hear me describe it when you can see it in action? Here, why don’t you come closer and take a look~ A new Prescript is about to be born!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The pendulum swings above the threads I spin, inscribing meaning on them.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Meaning? All I see are random patterns.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: It could seem hazy at first. This is the language of the City, after all. You obviously won’t recognize it, no-oh-no!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: The language of the City? Were there more languages left to be found…?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Mmm… It’s a different kind from the languages people use. Oh, it certainly is.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The thing is… I have no idea what it means, either~

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: But we’ll soon be able to find out.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: There are fifty-seven spinning wheels here.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The threads spun from those wheels are then put in this loom, and I modestly weave cloth from them.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Wait just a moment, now~

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: And there it is! Look. A Prescript has been created~!

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: No way…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …‘To Chae-heon. When you see a person on a three-way intersection waving their hand seven times, follow them to their house.’

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: It… really is a Prescript.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Alright~ No time to be spacing out! We should send this Prescript to a Messenger for delivery, right?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Start with this stamp, and…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: …Let’s see, let’s see~ The code is N… N… Next to L… N920… and 1…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: There it is! Pipe number N9201 is right here!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Now we roll up this Prescript and put it in here. The Prescript will travel along the pipe all the way to the surface.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: That’s what Prescripts were…?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: This can’t be… Who made the spinning wheels, the loom, and the pipes, then?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: I have no clue~ I was led here by a Prescript, too.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Oh—oh, my predecessor was waiting for me when I arrived~ But they left after receiving a Prescript one day.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Have you never questioned the Prescripts?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Not really? I don’t have much else to do, anyway.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Do you have any idea how many people died because of your stupid randomly generated commands…?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: If this is where all Prescripts are made… Then you could’ve at least tweaked them a little so they’re not as cruel.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: …I’m doing this because a Prescript ordered me to create and send Prescripts down here, though.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: If I broke this Prescript, the Prescripts will get me killed…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: What are you talking about! You’re the one in charge of sending out Prescripts!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: What if there’s another Weaver like me somewhere in another Nest?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: You don’t possibly think that I’m the only one mailing all the Prescripts for the City, do you?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Someone has to be making the contents of the Prescripts, but who could it be…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: In my opinion, that’d be the City itself.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The pendulum inscribing patterns on the threads swings according to the City’s motions, like I said just before.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Footsteps of pedestrians walking around on the surface… Quakes coming from construction sites… Impacts created from some clumsy person falling on the floor… Echoes of people’s screams…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Every little event happening in the City becomes a vibration that moves the pendulum.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Even the sound of us talking.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: At the end of the day, us City folk can never be free from the City.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Every deed committed by denizens of the City is ultimately the City’s deed. We’re representing its will in a sense.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: All the cruel things we’ve been committing were out of the City’s volition?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Why did the City… have to be that way?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Because the people are.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: The City was built by people, and their cruel nature had to naturally reflect on their creation.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: We were born that way.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: This is a mess… People built the City… and now the City is controlling the people…?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Does the order really matter much? I think the point is this! That whatever we do, we’re essentially part of the City.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: All you do is weave cloth in this peaceful bunker… You probably have no idea what kind of brutal outcomes that piece of cloth you make can bring.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: That’s why you can talk about this with such a carefree attitude…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: You’re right, that’s beyond me. I only do what I was ordered to do.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Do I really have to care about that, though?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: According to the City’s will, its volition… The City’s will matches the will of the people living in it.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Did you know?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: There are beings born out of the City folk’s wants.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Humans want to walk the path that’s given to them. They’re afraid to face the consequences of their actions and take responsibility for them.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: They know that they will only end up going the wrong way if they try to make their own decisions.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: They’d rather rely on something and expect things from it rather than to live a life of struggle.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: People without purpose in their lives desiring and yearning for something to open up a way for them…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: It could be someone wishing for equality amidst the savagery and voyeurism…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Or it could be the vain hopes of those who want the City to thrive forevermore, providing for all of its inhabitants…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: That’s how gods were born; people needed them.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: They didn’t pop into existence because someone told them to. They can’t be made up by anyone, nor can they be oppressed.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: You can’t blame anyone for this.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: So many people, so many residents of the City want them…

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Thus, they’re the fear that will draw near them, the temptation of happiness… The promises and wishes of all people.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Are you starting to get… why the Prescripts came into existence?

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Haha… Yeah.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Right… It wasn’t my fault.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: People weren’t doing inhumane things because I delivered Prescripts to them…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Those horrible things were meant to happen anyway.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: You’re right, I think I see it now.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: It’s the City… It’s because people have always been cruel. Humans are born that way… And they have desperate wishes.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: It doesn’t matter if they were pure wishes welled up from innocent hearts or ambitions born from greed, this is the result of what everyone wished for.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Killing people with my own hands, or taking away invaluable things from others…

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Shuddering in guilt listening to those horrid screams, while I tried my best to seem unfazed.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: They were all useless feelings eating away at my heart.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: …Exactly. I’m just a tiny part of the world, I can never change the wishes of all people… There’s no way I can defy this flow.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: What I did was part of the City… The will of the City.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Forging Prescripts out of spite and delivering them could be traced to the City’s volition, not my free will.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: But that equates to my volition in the end.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: The City and I… and every person in this City were one and the same.

Dialog.Title: Index Messenger
Dialog.Content: Do you think so, too?
…Moirai. The City must know where I should go next.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Huh? Me?

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: …Oh, don’t you worry. Just a moment, please~

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: …Alright, here. It’s an invitation to the Library. Prepared just for you.
…As the City wills it.

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: What was he talking to… Or was he talking to me all along? Well, regardless!

Dialog.Title: Index Weaver
Dialog.Content: Back to my post~ Gotta keep my position.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Color me speechless… So that’s what the Prescripts really were.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Beings… akin to gods of the City… I don’t think I’ve heard or read any mention of such things.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It does seem like there are some beings out there that fit the description that Weaver person gave. I think I’ve seen something similar a few times, though I don’t know if that actually was one.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Not sure if “being” is the right word for them, to be honest.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: They’re supposedly created because people wished for them to exist… I don’t know a lot about ‘em, to tell you the truth.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: According to her logic, the Prescripts would be one such being, created from the collective aspiration of those who want to be given a purpose in their aimless lives.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: So you’ve seen one yourself, Roland?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Dunno. I might have, but… I don’t really know what I saw. Heck, I’m not even sure if I saw it at all.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That doesn’t count as seeing one, does it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s just that my memory about the details of it is blurry. And I don’t feel like remembering it for whatever reason…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You don’t think highly of them, huh?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Seeing what one of those metaphorical gods made out of people’s wishes is doing… I can’t see them in a positive light.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They seem to lead people to ruin, in one way or another. Is it truly for their sake?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What do you think, Roland? Do you think those “gods” are leading the residents of the City to the correct paths as some claim?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I won’t lie that at a glance, they do look like a weird cult giving their lives to an object that swings on a whim.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And they’re giving arbitrary meanings to it like how it’s the heartbeat of the City. That’s a consequentialist point of view, shared by many other religions.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The methods they take may be a complete mess…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That being said, I don’t think that there’s absolutely nothing good to say about them. They fulfilled the people’s wishes anyhow.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The results… are another story.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Even though the so-called gods bring fear and despair to people, they get to live a life that’s richer and more human.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The goal might have been forcibly handed to them, but it’s still better than nothing.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, you’re free to think whatever you want in the end. You could feel the Prescripts are horrible, or a justified necessity, or whatever.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You’re right. Anyway… We should put our personal impressions aside and prepare to receive our guest.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’m counting on you as always.
Receive a Prescript… And carry it out…
Receive a Prescript… And carry it out…
Receive…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Greetings, dear guest.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: If I may, I am—
Angela…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Yes, it would seem that you know me well.
The Prescripts know everything.
The Prescripts represent the will of the City… They know everything that goes on in the City.
They know what I am going to do… What you are going to do. All of it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I… see.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Don’t you have any doubts about the Prescripts?
Of course not. The Prescripts are the City’s will, and the City’s volition is my will…
To deny the City’s volition is to deny myself.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: By accepting that as truth, you’re acknowledging that you have no free will of your own; don’t you feel that it is unfair?
We no longer have to be driven to despair by the repercussions of our choices… We don’t have to be worn down from the pain, standing in the field of thorns on our two feet.
By filling up the part that can’t be achieved alone, our lives as humans can become much more lavish.
I have the talent to walk the path in front of me, if nothing else… Even if I don’t have much happiness, I know where to go in the immediate future. And that’s enough for me.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …It’s fortunate to hear that you are satisfied with it.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: May you find your book in this place.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Could that person’s death be what the Prescripts intended?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Beats me. The Prescripts look like they see several steps ahead, so it might as well be.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Though, boy, what did that Yan guy endure and struggle so much for?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: He risked death forging Prescripts trying to express his free will…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: But that was ultimately part of the Prescripts… The will of the City, as he put it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Yep. After all, this is the fate those Prescripts led him to.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You said earlier that there are good things to be said about them, Roland.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That I did. ‘Cause they’re still part of the City.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: While I am still not completely convinced, I can understand it somewhat.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Life as a human, never wanting for anything…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What is the reason “gods” of the City emerged? Why do people wish for them to exist, even as they suffer?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I tried to think from those people’s perspectives. The perspective of someone without a purpose to live.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: How I would act in their shoes.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What’s your conclusion?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It couldn’t be more obvious: “I won’t sit and wait for someone else to determine the meaning of my life for me like the others.”

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: “I’m different.”

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: “I’ll seek out a way on my own.”

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It’s much easier said than done. They won’t truly realize what they’re talking about until they’re put in such a situation themselves.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So they can’t be viewed all that badly?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Correct. I’ve decided against painting them in an excessively negative light.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That still doesn’t mean I fully understand them, however.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Although, I am curious about what you just mentioned as well.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I must wonder what Yan’s actions and the consequences to them were trying to show.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Haven’t got a clue, ma’am~ Haven’t got a clue. Who’s to say what purpose there was to it in the first place.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Those Prescripts sure are an enigma…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And this whole Distortion business… It’s scary how the process can be so simple.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: That demonstration made it clearer. It appears that the breakdown of a belief one firmly held can serve as a catalyst for the Distortion.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Exactly. That’s the scary part. It’s what happens all the time in the City.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Though someone did explain to me why people aren’t distorting left and right pretty clearly.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Either way… This left a bitter taste in my mouth, just like that other time.
